Media: The New York Times
Review: <U+201C>A gorgeously sung, elementally spare production...The performers intermittently move through aisles in the audience, bringing an inviting intimacy to the production. It<U+2019>s a smart tactic, because while its score is continually beguiling, <U+2018>Hadestown<U+2019> might feel static were it not for Ms. Chavkin<U+2019>s simple but inventive staging...Ms. Mitchell<U+2019>s lovely music and well-turned lyrics are tightly bound together, and recall traditional folk music with a distinctive Southern flavor.

Media: Theatermania
Review: <U+201C>Chavkin has crafted a visually arresting production to match the richness of Mitchell's score...Chavkin and Mitchell enrich this ancient story in their imaginative rendering, making the characters and their relationships seem fresh and relatable...Everything about <U+2018>Hadestown<U+2019> is designed to grab your attention and pull you into the story. Even if you are not a fan of folk music, it will be difficult to resist this tuneful and visually spectacular production.<U+201D>

Media: The Hollywood Reporter
Review: <U+201C>The material has been given an enthralling environmental staging...Energetically sung by the powerful-voiced ensemble, the music is terrific: endlessly inventive and eclectic, as melodic as it is funky and folksy...The lyrics aren't as scintillating as the music, and the action feels overly busy at times. The dialogue can be wince-inducing...It hardly matters, thanks to the music's relentless energy and inventiveness as delivered by the crack band and terrific ensemble.<U+201D>

Media: New York Theater
Review: <U+201C>Mixes sweet and sexy folk, rocking New Orleans jazz, get-down blues and sinful soul. The eight cast members who perform the 35 songs are uniformly terrific; it<U+2019>s hard to imagine anybody better. If the plot strays little from the bare-bones story of Orpheus, the songs and the staging are enough to enchant for the two-hour running time...'Hadestown' is not a traditional musical. Think of it as a concert with benefits, but don<U+2019>t resist the temptation to go.<U+201D>

Media: The Huffington Post
Review: <U+201C>This interestingly told and interestingly staged journey to the Underworld, alas, only occasionally hits the heights...While we have a bunch of prettyish numbers...things don<U+2019>t get hot until we get the hell to Hades. The second act more thoroughly engages us and holds our attention...Fans of Mitchell<U+2019>s album will likely be wowed by the piece, and the stage version is a worthy attempt at trying something different. But this visit to 'Hadestown' is not quite compelling.<U+201D>

Media: Lighting & Sound America
Review: <U+201C>What's most engaging about <U+2018>Hadestown<U+2019> isn't the story it tells but the way it tells it -- with a barrelhouse sense of rhythm and plenty of blue notes. Under Chavkin's direction, the entire cast is in synch with the music's sassy, cynically upbeat mood, delivering each lyric with a lazy vibrato and a shrugging acknowledgement of the world's wicked ways...<U+2018>Hadestown<U+2019> delivers its tragic tale with a wink and a snap in its step.

Media: Front Row Center
Review: A thrilling new musical<U+2026>With her partner, director Rachel Chavkin and this magnificent design team and orchestra <U+2013> a thing of beauty has been created.  While at times it is is more concert than theatre (this was the first incarnation of the piece) the story nevertheless reaches out and grabs you in your wooden seat.

Media: Talkin' Broadway
Review: <U+201C>A testament to the rewards that can be reaped from conceiving an approach and sticking to it no matter what. Lots of theatre claims to be immersive, but few accomplish it as totally as <U+2018>Hadestown<U+2019> does. But for all its physical and technical brilliance, it's dull, even irritating, as an example of musical theatre writing...As with other recent stage efforts from pop artists, it has no discernible interest in telling its story on the theatrical terms.<U+201D>

Media: Broadway Blog
Review: For a show inspired by a tale dramatized in countless films, plays, and operas...it<U+2019>s disappointing to see how little drama has been squeezed from it here, despite the many appealing songs and the infusion of a capitalistic exploitation theme...With its extensive use of mics, and even a section where Persephone introduces each orchestra member for applause, it's basically a well-staged concert. Judging by the warm response, however, many will have a hot time in old Hadestown tonight.

Media: AM New York
Review: <U+201C>Proves to be smart and romantic but dramatically underwhelming...In Mitchell<U+2019>s hands, the sensitive Orpheus is too focused on playing the guitar to provide for Eurydice<U+2019>s real-world needs, so she independently ventures down to an industrialized underworld...The cast is excellent and songs are either gently touching or catchy, but <U+2018>Hadestown<U+2019> does come off as slow, undercooked and choppy, more reminiscent of a concert than a theatrical work.<U+201D>

Media: New York Magazine / Vulture
Review: <U+201C>The likelihood of enjoyment may depend on your willingness to accept that what you are watching is not in fact a musical but more of an illustrated pop concert, if a very pretty one. On the other hand, if you go in hoping for a story told through song, the traditional province of musical theater, you will be very much disappointed...Luckily the singing is generally excellent...When almost everything is narrated, the lack of variety dulls emotion and smothers the pulse.

Media: Time Out New York
Review: <U+201C>The stellar ensemble fills the theater with soaring harmonies, weaving in and out of the audience and the onstage band. Mitchell<U+2019>s music, lush and strange and lyrically brilliant, has found its match in this cast...The one weak spot is Daunno, whose vocal and acting chops don<U+2019>t stack up against his peers. Still, <U+2018>Hadestown<U+2019> is something special, a sensory feast that<U+2019>s also a passionate debate between pragmatism and romance.<U+201D>

Media: Deadline
Review: First recorded and performed as a concept album, the song cycle by Ana<U+00EF>s Mitchell is easy listening, sometimes sparkling<U+2026>Director Rachel Chavkin working with terrific design talent and superb jazz-meets-country orchestrations by Michael Chorney, provides a Tiffany setting for Mitchell<U+2019>s work...I didn<U+2019>t weep for E&O when he blew their escape plan in the end. But maybe it<U+2019>s me: The lady seated behind me, emoting heartily the show, was practically speaking in tongues by the end.

Media: CurtainUp
Review: In 'Hadestown' the old tale has been brought to fascinating, lushly staged new life<U+2026>Imperative for anyone who appreciates vibrant, original musicals. While 'Hadestown' hasn't completely shed its album-concert roots, it's not overstating anything when it describes itself as a folk opera...The real star of 'Hadestown' is the music with its well blended mix of folk music, blues-y jazz and pop...The lyrics are also very smart...'Hadestown' is highly original and enjoyable.

Media: Theatre Reviews Limited
Review: Ana<U+00EF>s Mitchell<U+2019>s 'Hadestown' is a faithful retelling of this epic myth with a deep connection to the present and the plight of the 99 percent. Orpheus<U+2019> journey to rescue Eurydice from Hades and death and the gripping journey of the pair to the very Gates of Hell has never been more clear or more compelling...Ms. Mitchell<U+2019>s scintillating 'Hadestown' quickens the deadliness of our current political maelstrom and the social ennui it so weakly attempts to address.

Media: The Wrap
Review: <U+201C>What Mitchell<U+2019>s music doesn<U+2019>t have is much dramatic drive. Song after song gives us a glimpse into the characters<U+2019> emotional state. Rarely are we further along in the story when someone finishes singing...Mitchell the lyricist is no match for Mitchell the composer. Her wordplay is intelligent, but rarely is it inspired...Rachel Chavkin<U+2019>s direction occasionally creates magnificent stage pictures, but the individual moments don<U+2019>t build.<U+201D>

Media: CitiTour
Review: Anais Mitchell<U+2019>s remarkably diverting musical...This highly original piece has been directed with great flair by the talented Rachel Chavkin<U+2026>Chavkin ensures that we are immersed fully in this captivating tale, since the cast often stands and dances before us (and even interacts with a few of us)<U+2026>Mitchell<U+2019>s magnificently varied score is the main attraction<U+2026>More importantly, each piece of the mostly sung-through score works beautifully in this theatrical setting.

Media: Broadway & Me
Review: Mitchell and the ever-inventive director Rachel Chavkin have transformed the song cycle into a theatrical piece that sticks close to the main storyline but they've added a down-home Louisiana vibe that is alternately sweet and peppery and deliciously satisfying...The multiracial cast is terrific, except for Damon Daunno's Orpheus who is charming but strains when his songs venture into falsetto<U+2026>Best of all, however, is Chris Sullivan, who plays the world-weary narrator Hermes.

Media: Financial Times (UK)
Review: Mitchell<U+2019>s version cleverly evokes the 'satanic mills' of industrialisation and the lonely romance of the railroads, but it<U+2019>s not quite enough to pad out the story for two hours. As directed and co-developed by Rachel Chavkin, 'Hadestown' thus feels more like a semi-staged concert (albeit an entertaining one) than a fully developed work of musical theatre. The ending in particular fails to extract much pathos from Orpheus<U+2019>s fatal backward glance.

Media: NJ.com
Review: <U+201C> ers one of the most enjoyable new scores this side of <U+2018>Hamilton<U+2019>...You feel as if you've slipped into a wormhole and landed in a New Orleans jazz joint circa the 1920s...The story of Orpheus and Eurydice doesn't quite justify a two-hour show, and the second act of 'Hadestown' feels flat...Still, good luck trying to get Mitchell's infectious, down-and-dirty melodies out of your head.<U+201D>

Media: Village Voice
Review: The Orpheus myth is about so much more than young love denied. And, luckily, singer-songwriter Ana<U+00EF>s Mitchell and director Rachel Chavkin celebrate such depths in the delightful new folk opera 'Hadestown'...The piece infuses the familiar Greek legend with sharp-edged commentary on capitalism, exuberant songs, and a complex meditation on love....Mitchell's best songs are raucous group numbers, expanding the characters' dilemmas into playful meditations on love and hardship.

Media: Epoch Times
Review: <U+201C>Tightly directed by Rachel Chavkin, who helped develop the piece, one feels literally a part of the story from beginning to end...The score, ranging from ballads to bluegrass, is brilliant...Page turns in a bravura performance as Hades, and Gray is wonderful as Persephone. Her performance captures both the exuberance of a bird in a flight and one trapped in a cage...With a story of love, loss, and rebirth both timeless and universal, <U+2018>Hadestown<U+2019> makes for a totally thrilling experience.

Media: Exeunt Magazine
Review: 'Hadestown' manages to be both simple in structure but complex in references...Most of the time the allegory works. Occasionally it is strained...It<U+2019>s a talented cast, and the music is so often devilishly enticing that it is easy to forgive it some dramaturgical gaps<U+2026>The love story could have used an injection of sizzle<U+2026>Beautiful harmonies and evocative performances keep it from drifting too far into the didactic. Chavkin and Mitchell craft a vivid space to explore a probing political agenda.

Media: Stage Buddy
Review: Put a great Greek myth together with an awesome genre-spanning score plus a superb cast and you get the downtown hit 'Hadestown'<U+2026>It hits with the full impact of the consequences of one fearful action<U+2026>Mr. Sullivan<U+2019>s stage presence is a study in 'less is more;' he is riveting and endearing as he moves the action along with his blues-tinged vocals, sometimes pulling out a harmonica to wail upon<U+2026>The lyrics are chilling and familiar in this election year. 'Hadestown' is not to be missed!
